document.text: Raymond Hale, colored desperado who was shot by Appomattox officers August 18 as he sought to escape as he was being lodged in the county jail, died in a Lynchburg hospital last Thursday afternoon. He left a record of crime and pol ice records extending over several states. As he shifted his movements he frequently changed his name, but he couldnt change his finger prints. His prints were forwarded to federal .authorities and reports  on his criminal career were furnish ed local officials. He lhad served time Sing Sing prison and in the Virginia pen and many jails, mostly on robbery charges, and was want ed as an escaped prisoner. Deputy sheriff D . A . Conner was the local officer who brought down Hale. Technical charges lagainjt Mr. Conner were dismissed at trial justices court here yesterday. Hale had been arrested here on charges of robbing a filling station and of stealing an auto. He is said to have admitted both charges. His past re cord was obviously the reason for his attempt to get out of the Ap pomattox jail. Back in May, 1925, under the name of Scott White, Hale was sent to the Virginia pen for six years, on two counts of housebreaking. He escaped June 25, 1925 and not until November3, 1933 was he re turned. In 1925 he was sentenced to a year for second offense grand larceny in New York, ln January, 1926 he ran afoul of New York law again for attempted burglary. Under the name of James Brown he was sentenced to five years in Sing Sing on June 1, 1927. Feb ruary, 1932 saw him jailed at Fort Lee, N .J. He spent 2 years in a New Jersey prisonand then was turned over to Virginia officials.

She was a daughter of John Henry, of Red Bank, Charlotte county, and a sister of the late William W irt Henry, of Richmond. It is said that the promise made to the National Episcopal Convention at Boston last year is the cause of the move which will result in the rebuild ing of the Jefferson Hotel, Richmond, between now and 1907 . When the con vention was asked to meet in Richmond two years hense the objection was raised that at least 5,000 persons would attend, and Richmond did nht have adequate ho tel accommodations. But Mr. Joseph Bryan, who presented the invitation, pledged himself to see that the accom modations were adequate. The result j has been that he is now at the head oi a company of capitalists which will spend hundreds of thousands of dollars in re storing the hotel, half of which has been in ruins for years. Robert L. Nobles, a young barber, re siding in Petersburg, attempted to cut his throat with a razor in the presence of his sister. Nobles succeeded in cut ting a deep and long gash under his throat before his sister could wrench the razor from his hand. He had been drinking. H ewas taken to the police station, where his worind was dressed, and then was sent to jail. The capital stock of  300,000 of the new national bank to be established in Petersburg has all been subscribed. The bank is also to have a surplus fund of  30 , 000 . Augustus Wright is to be president of the new institution, which expects to begin operations in a short time. G. A. Fritz, of Petersburg, has pur chased of Joseph Mussons  Son, of Sandusky, Ohio, their stallion Red Star Shine for  1 , 000 . It has been some months since there has been a steamer running on the Appomat tox River. They represent a shapely girl clad in tights, who hangs by her knees from a trapeze, smoking a ciagarette and holding a bag of the new tobacco in her hand. When a salesman started to put up these hangers he was stopped by a policeman, who warned him to desist until he had seen the Mayor. Ash by Walts, which lie thought was a forgery. A close watch was kept over Routen for a short time and the officer accosted him and demanded the check. Routen declared that lie did not have a check. The.officer was now positive that he did have the instrument and told him if lie did not produce it he would have to lock him up. Routen pleaded that the nippers be not put on him, prom ising to accompany the officer with out trouble. He said he did not want to attract attention on the streets. Mr. Glanner, having just gone off duty for the day, did not have his club with him, and the pair started up Ninth street for the po lice headquarters. Knowing that if the man did not have the check, the officer kept a close watch on him in order to detect any effort to dispose of the evidence that would be strong against him if found on his person. All went well until Church street was passed when about half way up the steps to Court street Mr. Gluun- er saw Routen place a piece of paper in his mouth. Quick as a flash he designed the purpose of the prisoner. He did not have long to go over the situation until the check would have been swallowed, and with it would have disappeared any evidence that he might have against Routen. Without the slightest hesitation the officer pounced on his unsuspecting prisoner and began to choke him iu order to prevent him from destroy ing the check. Routen is a power ful man, but the strength and agili ty of the officer was too much for him. In less time than is required to relate the incident, the tongue of the man popped out his mouth, which was uow wide opeu in his fran tic efforts, to regain his breath. With Routen leaning over the rail at the side of the steps, it was now an easy matter for the officer to insert the fingers of his other hand and remove therefrom the check, damp and somewhat dilapidated for its experi ence, but still intact. About this tune Officers Metts and Harris ran up and the rest was easy. Routen was taken to the police head quarters, where formal charges were made against him, and later he was locked up at the city jail. Mr. Watts was seen yesterday even ing, and he stated that he had not, given the man a check. The instru ment was for 50 and was drawn on the National Exchange Bank. Routen endeavored to have the paper cashed at several stores, and also tried one or two persons on the streets in vain, the amount being too large for persons at that time of the day to cash, even if they were dis posed to do so. It is impossible for this young mans friends to account for his act, unless he did it in adit of desperation,caused by dissipation. document.text: Grover Steele, superintendent of the Appomattox Court House lined an ambitious program of construction and rehabilitation of park buildings during the last Lions Club meeting and a spec ial interview with the TIMES- VIRQfJilAN. We hope to have all this done before the Centen nial, he said as he checked over a long list of projects. The Old! Court House is well underway, Steele said, with the village fenc ing almost complete. Both of these contracts were awarded J. E. Jamerson and Sons, local construction firm. He listed the rehabilitation and stabilization! of the old county jail as an important project. Ex plaining that the jail did not fig ure in the peace negotiations of 1865, nor the laying down of arms by Confederates, Steele said that nonetheless the old jail, constructed in the 1860s, holds much interest for visitors. The walls are very Strong, he said, and the structure has in teresting innovations to prevent escape. Those innovations in clude heavy iron bars, plus rings embedded in the floor of one cell to which prisoners might be shackled. Steele mentioned that the jail originally had a plaster ed interior. Plans are to retain one room of the jail in its pre sent condition to show the origi nal construction. New Entrance Road Preliminary drawings .have been completed, he said, for the new entrance road and parking area to be located about one- quarter of a mile west of the present road. After the new road and parking area is finish ed, which should be sometime in 64, he said, we will proceed with the restoration of the his toric Lynchburg - Richmond stage road. As a part of the plan to restore the old village to its 1865 appearance, all utility and power lines will be buried underground. We hope to achive a feeling of an historical village Steele said. Extensive archeological studies were made last year, he added, and we hope to complete the the three McLean House out buildings very soon. These in clude an ice house, slave quart ers, and kitchen. Mariah Wright House Funds have already been ap propriated for the restoration of the Mariah Wright house, Steele said. Congress also appropriated funds to include the construction of the Bocock-Isball stable. All of the Court House park restoration comes from an act of Congress, June 18, 1930, which provided 100,000 to commem- ororate the end of the War Be tween the States. document.text: Appomattox County History As a political division of the state, Appomattox County was formed in 1845 from the f o u r countiesBuckingham, Campbell, Prince Edward, and Charlotteand named for one of the Indian . tribes whose home was in thé state. Its area is small and its people fewer than the average in the Southside counties. Located in the dark -tobacco belt, its money crop is tobacco, but corn, timber and dairy products are of consideration. Appomattox, the county seat is a tobacco market. The town has grown up near the Norfolk and Western Railway, three miles from tthe old Appo mattox Court House which has ceased to exist. The new courthouse is at the newer county seat, the countys larg est town. Aside from its own industrial and commercial in vests, Appomattox is a trad ing center for a considerable territory. Pamplin, a smaller town, has the distinction of being the home of the largest clay pipe kilns in the world. Tobacco reated the business, but the demand for this great nico tine absorber which excels al the meerschaums has kep these kilns for a good many years a flourishing industry. The daily output is  25,000 pipes. Three miles from the county seat lie some hundreds of ac res often spoken of as the Sur render Grounds To the Vir ginian, this is Appomattoxa name synonymous with the melting away of thé last Gray army, -the return to dévastée farms, to ruined and desolate homes, to bereaved and sun dered families synonymous with the hopeless poverty of means to feed the hungry mouths of loved ones to fine provender few faithful teer vants who, like helpless child rc-n, were still their charge, synonymous with crushed ana bioken spirits, with Virginia desolation and despair. One standing on the Surrender c-i nds today sees nothing but meek and ruina symbol of the desoialem of Virginia ane her people, April 9, 1865. The old Appomattox Court House was destroyed by fire in 1892 the McLean Housefor a long time the only note to 3often f,the somberness of the scenewas torn down for re moval to the Chicago Worlds Fair, but was never taken away. All that remains are some piles of rotting lumber and some bricks such as have remained intact one upon .an other in the walls. The old tavern, no longer a place of rest for the weary traveler journeying over the old stage road, still stands, but with the pathetic and desolate look of a place going to decay. The old jail is still there, but emp ty now. The place of the courthouse and the county seat have been moved over to the new town that has grown up three miles away. Years ago the Federal Government placed many markers tü guide the visitor to notable places on the Field. Many of these are gone the standards have de cayed and the njetal guides are halfburied in the ground, or repose in the gullies made by the washing rains. Two monuments are herememo rials to the Confederate Cause  one was erected by North Caro lina, the other by Virginia. A Surrender Field, yes an end and a beginning.
